tropeNotes: [Child of Two Worlds](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/ChildOfTwoWorlds): In the 3D version (SPOILER)  it's revealed that the party were born on the surface world and came to the floating continent with Cid Haze as a consequence of Xande unleashing the flood of darkness. However, this is [not touched upon later in the game](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/AbortedArc) outside of unused text hinting at Ingus' hometown and that Luneth remembers the airship crash.
[The Chosen Many](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/TheChosenMany): Four kids were chosen by the crystals to save the world.

[Color-Coded Characters](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/ColorCodedCharacters): The four starting Onion Knights have differing color palettes to set them apart, the colors being red, blue, green and another red (though occasionally appearing purple on the menu). The DS version[pays tribute](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/MythologyGag) to this by color-coding the party members in the opposite order from the Famicom lineup while *[Dissidia Final Fantasy NT](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/VideoGame/DissidiaFinalFantasyNT)* would give Onion Knight palettes based on three of the four Onion Knights. Averted with the manga heroes as their color palettes change on each manga cover.

[Conveniently an Orphan](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/ConvenientlyAnOrphan): Something all three groups have in common is that they're orphans and they're chosen by the crystals. The 3D version both [lampshades](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/LampshadeHanging) and somewhat justifies it by revealing that  (SPOILER)  the warriors are not native to the Floating Continent and came from the surface world .

[Depending on the Writer](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/DependingOnTheWriter): Whether or not the characters from the 3D version or *Dissidia*'s interpretation based on the Famicom originals are the canon protagonists varies. Material pertaining to *III* directly will use the 3D version's protagonists while crossovers such as *Dissidia* or *Theatrhythm* will use Onion Knight. It gets particularly odd in mobages such as *Brave Exivus* or *Record Keeper* where you can use both the 3D version's protagonists *and* Onion Knight, though *Record Keeper* does acknowledge it in [special dialogue](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/EasterEgg) and Onion Knights' soul breaks. Meanwhile, the manga uses its own set of characters, although that's justified given how early it was made.

[Divergent Character Evolution](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/DivergentCharacterEvolution): The original Onion Knights did not have distinct personalities nor any defining characteristics outside of their armor color, which became irrelevant as soon as Jobs became available. The manga diverged them into three boys and one girl, each with distinct appearances and quirks while dropping the Onion Knight motif. The DS version followed suit with its protagonists who were differentiated even further with wardrobes that carried over into the design of their job outfits and having two of the four orphans not end up in Topapa's care. Meanwhile, the Onion Knight seen in *Dissidia*, whilst still based on the original Famicom heroes, is a character in his own right and has his own identity beyond any of the other protagonists.

[Inconsistent Coloring](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/InconsistentColoring):
    - The fourth Onion Knight: His armor is the same shade of red as the first, yellow - The manga protagonists tend to have different color schemes across the few colored illustrations they get (such as Muuchi's hair being brown in some illustrations and black in others). Doug is probably the most extreme example, usually being blond and having an association with green and yellow except in at least one case where his hair is silver and his clothes are blue and yellow. - Subverted with Luneth: [Onion Knight's](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/VideoGame/DissidiaFinalFantasy) *Luneth* costume associates him with the color blue rather than the usual purple, likely to make him a [Composite Character](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/CompositeCharacter) with the unnamed warrior from the artwork of the original version of III note  When Onion Knight got a proper version of a costume based on said artwork character in *Duodecim*, it used a black outfit variant based on a certain art piece . However both the Japanese name of the costume and Onion Knight's personality hint that, while invocative of him, it isn't actually Luneth.
[Inconsistent Spelling](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/InconsistentSpelling): Their title's exact phrasing varies between "Warriors of Light" and "Warriors of *the* Light", depending on the translation.

[Kid Hero](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/KidHero): Their youth is remarked upon several times, though never specifically given. The DS and manga protagonists are more closer to teenagers than children, although the party in general is still among the youngest in a *Final Fantasy* game <sup>note </sup>  For reference's sake: Zidane is the second youngest FF main character at age 16. Muuchi, from the manga, is age 15 and Luneth and Onion Knight are implied to be around that age, if not younger .
[Light Is Good](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/LightIsGood): As counterparts to the equally-benevolent [Warriors of Darkness](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/DarkIsNotEvil).

[Made of Iron](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/MadeOfIron): They survive *two* airship crashes and end up no worse for wear. The 3D version references this in a darker context by  (SPOILER)  introducing a *third* crash to the game via the updated backstory: Cid was ferrying an airship full of people on the day the flood of darkness happened, and the only survivors were himself and the four orphans.

[Naughty Is Good](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/NaughtyIsGood): To varying degrees depending on the group: On one end, Luneth is the only mischevious one of his group and that's partially due to [his nature](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/InnocentlyInsensitive); on the opposite end is Muuchi, Doug and J Bowie from early in the manga, who are shown to trick and steal from merchants, to the ire of Toppapa and later Melfi.

[The Smurfette Principle](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/TheSmurfettePrinciple): Played straight in both the manga and the 3D version which have a single girl among the group, averted in the original where the four orphans were all boys, [not that it means much](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/FeaturelessProtagonist).

[Symbol Motif Clothing](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/SymbolMotifClothing): In the DS version, each of the four heroes has a particular symbol or patterning in their shown Freelancer/normal clothing that pops up in many of their job outfits. Luneth has the pattern of his vest of belts and a 3x3 checkered pattern similar to them, Arc has the "X" shown on his belt buckle or his yellow scarf, Refia has the cross on the clasp of her vest, and Ingus has the teardrop shape of his pendant, or just continues to wear it. [Here's](http://images.wikia.com/finalfantasy/images/b/ba/FF3-WhiteMage.png)◊ [a](http://images.wikia.com/finalfantasy/images/6/6b/FF3-Knight.png)◊ [few](http://images.wikia.com/finalfantasy/images/5/54/FF3-Magus.png)◊ [examples](http://images.wikia.com/finalfantasy/images/d/d8/FF3-Viking.png)◊.

[Trauma-Induced Amnesia](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/TraumaInducedAmnesia): In the 3D version, it's implied that a combination of this and childhood amnesia is why  (SPOILER)  the warriors could not remember that they came from the surface world, or even that there was a surface world to begin with. Unused text further complicates it by showing that Luneth and Ingus vaguely remember the airship crash and his hometown respectively, along with the mountain range near the Cave of Shadows, while Arc and Refia show no sign of remembering anything prior to their lives on the floating continent.

[Weapon Specialization](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/WeaponSpecialization):
    - The manga heroes have specific weapons they favor in combat: Muchi uses [a sword](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/HeroesPreferSwords), Doug has [a bendable stick with a spikeball on the end](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/EpicFlail), Melfi has a bow and arrows as well being proficient in [white magic](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/WhiteMage), and J Bowie sometimes wields a staff while other times relying on [physical prowess](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/GoodOldFisticuffs). In either case, he also uses [black magic](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/BlackMage). - The remake heroes don't have specific weapons, so much as specific jobs that they are usually portrayed as in supplementary material such as the opening (with [certain exceptions](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/VideoGame/FinalFantasyRecordKeeper)): Luneth is a [Warrior](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/TheBerserker), Arc is a [Black Mage](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/BlackMage), Refia is a [White Mage](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/WhiteMage) and Ingus is a [Red Mage](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/RedMage). Of course, during gameplay, you can make them any class you'd like. - Lastly, the Onion Knight of *Dissidia* uses not only his namesake, but also the [Sage and Ninja jobs](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/InfinityPlusOneSword), based on their Famicom portrayal.

[Canon Name](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/CanonName): [Averted](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/Averted). The original game didn't give the Onion Knights names and most media at the time didn't use consistent names. The manga adaptation, *Yūkyū no Kaze Densetsu: Final Fantasy III Yori* uses the names Muuchi, Doug, Melfi and J.Bowie, but the manga also toes a line between [Pragmatic Adaptation](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/PragmaticAdaptation) and [In Name Only](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/InNameOnly) and those names are not used outside of it. After the release of the DS version, screenshots and gameplay of the Famicom version in media such as the Ultimania or *Theatrhythm*'s EMS sequence use the same names as the DS protagonists (Luneth, Arc, Refia and Ingus). However, in *Dissidia Final Fantasy*, the Onion Knight in that game who is based more closely on the Famicom heroes [simply goes by Onion Knight or variations of the name](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/EveryoneCallsHimBarkeep). Worth mentioning is that this specific Onion Knight's Japanese name is written in Katakana (オニオンナイト).

[Composite Character](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/CompositeCharacter):
    - *[Dissidia Final Fantasy](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/VideoGame/DissidiaFinalFantasy)* would represent the original Onion Knights via a single Onion Knight who appears as the *FFIII* hero representative, a trend that would continue with later crossover games. Leans into [ZigZag territory](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/ZigZaggedTrope) as, although his descriptions occasionally mention his other three friends [we have yet to see them](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/TheGhost). - In a less straightforward example, Luneth's personality seems to be the closest to the original Onion Knights. - Goes in the opposite direction in *Final Fantasy Record Keeper* where, despite the sprite being based on the class' appearances prior to Dissidia, Onion Knight's soul breaks and easter egg dialogue make it clear he's based on the Dissidia interpretation. The release of the III-themed [Dreambreaker](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/HarderThanHard) dungeon in 2020 *finally* adds a dress record based on the Dissidia interpretation named "Cosmic Onion Knight".

[Featureless Protagonist](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/FeaturelessProtagonist): The many [NPCs](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/NPC) whom you meet have more personality (and more to say) than your Kids do. The only thing setting them apart is their [color schemes](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/PaletteSwap) when using the Onion Knight job.

[Guest Fighter](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/GuestFighter): A singular Onion Knight representing them appears in Dissidia and this interpretation goes on to appear in its various spinoffs. An Onion Knight closer to the original depiction is the basis for the class' appearance in *Brave Exivus* with the Dissidia Onion Knight also appearing as a CG unit.
[Heroic Mime](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/HeroicMime): Averted; Even in the original 8-bit version they have dialogue.

[Lost in Translation](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/LostInTranslation): The use of Onion in their initial class name, apparently, was meant to mean something like "beginner," or generally meant to invoke that they're inexperienced. In English, it just sounds like the vegetable.

[Vague Age](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/VagueAge): They're said to be youthful, but it doesn't give a clear idea of what age they are. Even the adaptations do not clear up matters: Both the manga and the DS version portray the heroes as teenagers, but *Dissidia*'s Onion Knight appears to be a child.

[Adaptational Nice Guy](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/AdaptationalNiceGuy): *Memory of Heroes* tones down Luneth's [Innocently Insensitive](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/InnocentlyInsensitive) traits, with his recklessness coming from his habit of sacrificing himself for his allies.
[The Berserker](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/TheBerserker): Fitting his reckless nature, his usual job is the Warrior job, which has an ability that sacrifices defense in favor of attack power.
[Blow You Away](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/BlowYouAway): He uses wind-based attacks in *[Final Fantasy Record Keeper](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/VideoGame/FinalFantasyRecordKeeper)*.

[Bully Hunter](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/BullyHunter): The [children teasing Arc](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/KidsAreCruel) at the beginning of the game flee when they see him, implying that he's this, at least where Arc is concerned.

[Bullying a Dragon](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/BullyingADragon): He and Ingus were initially willing to stand their ground against *Bahamut* (although, just a dragon as far as they knew at the time) in-spite of Desch's warning to run.
[Casting a Shadow](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/CastingAShadow): He can use Darkness abilities in *Record Keeper* and he has a Dark Knight counterpart in *Brave Exivus*.
[The Chosen One](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/TheChosenOne): By the Wind Crystal. [Though all of them are](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/TheChosenMany), Luneth brings them together.
[Colour-Coded for Your Convenience](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/ColourCodedForYourConvenience): Purple, derived from his sweater.

[Composite Character](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/CompositeCharacter):
    - To an degree, he's one to the four Onion Knights from the original game, retaining their backstory and being closest in personality to them. His silver hair with a ponytail also calls to mind the warrior from Amano's artwork for *III*. - In both *Record Keeper* and *Brave Exvius*, Luneth vaguely acted as one to Dissidia's Onion Knight prior to the latter joining the games, to the extent of having two of his moves (Swordshower and Blade Torrent) as special moves/Soul Breaks. The *Brave Exvius* example is a bit more notable as Swordshower is exclusive to Luneth and neither version of Onion Knight nor Onion Knight Refia can use it.

[Constantly Curious](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/ConstantlyCurious): The game opens as he falls through a hole [he was investigating, subsequently leading him to the Wind Crystal](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/CuriosityIsACrapshoot).

[Cryptic Background Reference](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/CrypticBackgroundReference): Not nearly as much as Ingus, but a unused scene reveals that he is vaguely aware of once being on an airship. Additionally, in both a scene in the final game and the unused text, he is shown to vaguely remember  (SPOILER)  the airship crash that brought them to the floating continent .
[Deadpan Snarker](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/DeadpanSnarker): Moreso in the unused text (especially towards Refia).

[Déjà Vu](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/DejaVu): In one of Cid's scenes directly after crashing the airship in Nelv Valley, Luneth gets a feeling that they've done that before  (SPOILER)  suggesting that he has vague memories of the airship crash that made the party orphans . The unused text shows a similar scene in the Wrecked Ship, where Luneth cryptically says  (SPOILER)  that they've seen a destroyed ship before .

[Dual Wielding](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/DualWielding): He dual-wields, like everyone else, in the opening. His appearance in *[Final Fantasy Brave Exvius](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/VideoGame/FinalFantasyBraveExvius)* also has him wield a longsword and a knife, and he's one of the few characters in that game to be able to do this innately.
[Fearless Fool](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/FearlessFool): His adventurous nature gets him into trouble a few times.

[Glass Cannon](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/GlassCannon): His usage of the Warrior job makes him one by extension. *Brave Exvius* runs with this further via his STMR reward: "Luneth's Clothes" gives an impressive attack boost... along with having a *single*point of defense.

[Guest Fighter](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/GuestFighter): He makes appearances in *Pictlogica Final Fantasy* (both normal and Viking), *Final Fantasy Airbourne Brigade*, *Final Fantasy Record Keeper*, and *Final Fantasy Brave Exivus*. Additionally, one of Onion Knight's unlockable costumes in *[Dissidia Final Fantasy](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/VideoGame/DissidiaFinalFantasy)* and it's sequel gives him Luneth's hairstyle, named *Luneth* (*Luneth-Style* in Japan) in Duodecim.

[Headbutting Heroes](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/HeadbuttingHeroes): A [Downplayed](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/Downplayed) example with Refia, which is much more explicit in the unused text where he's prone to teasing her, much to her annoyance.
[The Hero](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/TheHero): He's the first character controlled by the player and represents the party.
[Innocently Insensitive](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/InnocentlyInsensitive): He's not good at tact and either unintentionally insults, or he teases out of place.
[The Leader](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/TheLeader): A Type III, Headstrong. He leads the others by charging in, and their more mature and/or cautious natures keep him in check.
[Jumped at the Call](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/JumpedAtTheCall): Due to his adventurous personality.
[Manly Man and Sensitive Guy](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/ManlyManAndSensitiveGuy): He's the Manly Man to Arc's Sensitive Guy.
[Sailor's Ponytail](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/SailorsPonytail): He has a ponytail and he's the most adventurous of the group.
[Spell Blade](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/SpellBlade): He can use Spellblade abilities in *Record Keeper*.

[Too Many Belts](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/TooManyBelts): Though quite tame in comparison to the likes of [Lulu](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/VideoGame/FinalFantasyX) and others who made the trope famous, Luneth stands out for having a *vest* made up of three large, thick belts wrapped around his torso. The patterning of said vest reappears on many of his outfits in the different jobs.

[Treasure Hunter](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/TreasureHunter): In the unused text, he gets excited over the possibility of treasure, and discussion of it usually makes him more interested in the subject at hand.

[Vague Age](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/VagueAge): Unlike Arc and Refia, his age never comes up neither in the full game nor the unused text, leaving it unclear just how old he's supposed to be. Presumably however (especially depending on how one interprets his interactions with Aria) he would be around 15 years old.

[Vitriolic Best Buds](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/VitriolicBestBuds):
    - Another [Downplayed](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/Downplayed) case with Ingus, once again more explicit in the unused text: While he and Luneth do occasionally look down on the other, though [not nearly as much as the opening would lead one to believe](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/TrailersAlwaysLie), they also hold an amount of respect for each other that Luneth and Refia's [relationship](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/HeadbuttingHeroes) lacks. - *Memory of Heroes* plays it more straight between himself and Ingus, due to Ingus [being more of a](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/AdaptationalJerkass) [Deadpan Snarker](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/DeadpanSnarker).

tropeName: Why Did It Have to Be Snakes?
tropeNotes: [Why Did It Have to Be Snakes?](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/WhyDidItHaveToBeSnakes): Not to the same extent as Refia, but a scrapped running gag would have Luneth be hesitant to board an airship due to getting seasick (airsick?). There *is* one remnant of this in the final game, but it's so non-specific that it's likely to go over one's head unless they are aware of it in the first place  <sup>note </sup>  The scene where Desch suggests that the party see Argus about airships, Luneth mutters that he doesn't have fond memories of his last airship ride—which in context, seems like a reference to crashing their last one into a boulder .

[Adaptational Wimp](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/AdaptationalWimp): [Downplayed](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/Downplayed). In a reversal to Refia; while he is usually the Black Mage of the group, *[Final Fantasy Record Keeper](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/VideoGame/FinalFantasyRecordKeeper)* portrayed him as a White Mage, presumably to accommodate for Desch. That said, he still has decent access to Black Magic as well as being heavily proficient in summon magic (which even [Onion Knight](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/JackOfAllTrades) doesn't have) meaning he doesn't suffer too badly from this trope for it.

[Ascended Extra](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/AscendedExtra): In a way, and not quite to the same extent as Ingus, but a skittish NPC camped out on the outskirts of Kazus was absorbed into Arc when he was implemented into the 3D version, possibly serving as the basis for some of Arc's own timidity.

[Badass Bookworm](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/BadassBookworm): He's generally seen as the smartest of the quartet. In the unused text strings he's usually the one to give advice on how to handle bosses and is generally the first to realize when something's wrong (such as questioning why Gutsco took the horn in the first place). The image is further increased if one puts him in the Scholar job.
[Badass Longcoat](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/BadassLongcoat): He wears a overcoat and proves to be strong after his [Character Development](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/CharacterDevelopment).
[Big Brother Mentor](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/BigBrotherMentor): He becomes this to Prince Alus of Saronia.

[Black Mage](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/BlackMage):
    - This is his class of choice in the opening and promotional artwork. - He's also one in *[Final Fantasy Brave Exvius](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/VideoGame/FinalFantasyBraveExvius)*, complete with a magic rod and a [spell book](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/SpellBook). He also got a 5* variant that is based explicitly on his Black Mage Job.
[Brainy Brunette](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/BrainyBrunette): He loves books and learning and he's got brown-hair.

[Character Development](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/CharacterDevelopment): The most clear example of the four, Arc goes from a coward to a hero in his own right. This is best shown by comparing him at the beginning of the game (being bullied by the other kids and needing Luneth to help him) to near the end (practically lead the Light Warriors during Saronia and rescuing Alus from a gang of bullies).
[Colour-Coded for Your Convenience](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/ColourCodedForYourConvenience): Green, derived from his coat.
[Curtains Match the Window](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/CurtainsMatchTheWindow): Brown eyes, brown hair.

[Cute Bookworm](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/CuteBookworm): A male example. Towards the beginning of the game, Arc is shy and needs Luneth to protect him from bullies. He later develops into a [Badass Bookworm](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/BadassBookworm) over the course of the game.
[Foil](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/Foil): To Luneth. His official character blurb draws attention to the differences between them.
[Guest Fighter](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/GuestFighter): Appears in *Pictlogica Final Fantasy*, *Final Fantasy Airbourne Brigade*, *Final Fantasy Record Keeper*, and *Final Fantasy Brave Exivus*.

[Hearing Voices](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/HearingVoices): In *Memory Of Heroes*, he claims Bahamut spoke to him when none of the other heroes (or at the very least Luneth) seem to hear.  (SPOILER)  During the final battle against the Cloud of Darkness, Bahamut apparently continues to speak to him in this fashion right before Arc summons him.
[Height Angst](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/HeightAngst): It is hinted that Arc is upset with how short he is.

[Jack of All Trades](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/JackOfAllTrades): In *Final Fantasy Record Keeper*, Arc's able to utilize the three main classes of magic, although he's more suited for White and Summon magic than Black magic.

[Making a Splash](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/MakingASplash): His element in *Final Fantasy Record Keeper* as a Summoner, when he's not playing the offensive [White Mage](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/WhiteMage).
[Manly Man and Sensitive Guy](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/ManlyManAndSensitiveGuy): The Sensitive Guy to Luneth's Manly Man.
[Not So Weak](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/NotSoWeak): Especially when he sees Alus being bullied.
[Robe and Wizard Hat](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/RobeAndWizardHat): His final upgraded appearance in *Brave Exvius* gives him this look by combining his overcoat with a Black Mage hat.
[Scarf of Asskicking](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/ScarfOfAsskicking): It appears in quite a few of his jobs too.
[Shrinking Violet](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/ShrinkingViolet): At first he's very shy and can't stand up for himself. He develops during the Mognet sidequest and especially after meeting Alus.
[The Smart Guy](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/TheSmartGuy): He's usually the one to explain something, especially in the unused text.
[The So-Called Coward](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/TheSoCalledCoward): He's often called a coward by his peers. But he is the first person who goes to Kazus, where it was rumored to be haunted.
[Straw Vulcan](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/StrawVulcan): Tells everyone in the beginning that there are no ghosts in Kazus and goes there to prove it. (He is technically right, though.)
[Summon Magic](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/SummonMagic): He has access to summon magic in *Record Keeper* and he becomes a summoner for the finale of *Memory of Heroes*.

[White Mage](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/WhiteMage): This is his class in *Final Fantasy Record Keeper*, unlike most of his appearances where he's the black mage. Downplayed in practice as, while White Magic is still one of his greatest strengths, he has access to summons and, to a lesser extent, black magic.
[Youthful Freckles](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/YouthfulFreckles): He looks the youngest and has freckles to back the image.

[Abhorrent Admirer](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/AbhorrentAdmirer): Heavily downplayed given that he doesn't necessarily have a crush on her, but in a cut subplot for Duster, a bard was to see Refia as his muse, much to her discomfort.

[Adaptational Badass](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/AdaptationalBadass): *[Final Fantasy Record Keeper](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/VideoGame/FinalFantasyRecordKeeper)* took her Action Girl and blacksmith characterizations even further and turned her into a fire-elemental [Barefisted Monk](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/BarefistedMonk) who is one of the strongest physical fighters in the game. On the other hand...

[Adaptational Wimp](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/AdaptationalWimp): *[Final Fantasy Brave Exvius](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/VideoGame/FinalFantasyBraveExvius)* went the exact opposite way with her [White Mage](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/WhiteMage) characterization, turning her into one of the best healers in the game whose victory animation involves a chocobo running in from offscreen who Refia then prompty hugs.
    - Later on in *[Final Fantasy Brave Exvius](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/VideoGame/FinalFantasyBraveExvius)*, Refia gets a second, "Onion Knight" form (in the same update as Luneth's "Dark Knight" version mentioned above), which brings her back to [Adaptational Badass](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/AdaptationalBadass).
[Affirmative Action Girl](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/AffirmativeActionGirl): She's the second example of a female party member in the group, following Melfi from the manga.

[The Apprentice](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/TheApprentice): Her adopted father Takka is Kazus' local [blacksmith](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/TheBlacksmith) and wants her to follow in his footsteps. Unfortunately, Refia has no interest in smithing and takes a rebellious attitude towards her father's attempts to teach her.

[Bare-Fisted Monk](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/BareFistedMonk): In addition to possibly being one of these in the game itself, *Record Keeper* has her as a monk rather than her usual [White Mage](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/WhiteMage) job.
[Colour-Coded for Your Convenience](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/ColourCodedForYourConvenience): Blue, derived from her vest.

[Composite Character](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/CompositeCharacter):
    - [The only protagonist from the 3D version to avert this](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/AvertedTrope). Refia is the only one of the four not to be based on either the Onion Knights or an already existing NPC. - Done in the opposite direction in *World of Final Fantasy* where she retains her personality, but her story arc is a combination of her backstory and Alus' story arc.

[Cute Bruiser](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/CuteBruiser): Never has any qualms or troubles with fighting, and she made it from Kazus to the desert on her own at the beginning of the game. *Record Keeper* takes it further by making her the Monk of the III realm.
[Fiery Redhead](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/FieryRedhead): She may be the Light of Affection, but getting on her bad side is still an unwise idea.

[Guest Fighter](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/GuestFighter): Probably has the most exposure of the 3D version's protagonists; In addition to *Pictlogica Final Fantasy*, *Final Fantasy Airbourne Brigade*, *Final Fantasy Record Keeper* and *Final Fantasy Brave Exivus*, She was a signet in *Final Fantasy Dimensions II* and she also appeared in the much more mainstream *World of Final Fantasy*.

[Hair Color Dissonance](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/HairColorDissonance): Between her artwork, variable shadings of her official renders, and spin-off appearances, her hair color ranges from a light strawberry blond to an deep orange-red.

[Headbutting Heroes](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/HeadbuttingHeroes): With Luneth. It's much more explicit in the unused text, though shades of it remain in the final game and one of her quotes in *Brave Exvius*.
[The Heart](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/TheHeart): She has a warm and caring nature, albeit tempered by a sense of no-nonsense and willingness to tell off those who deserve it.

[Interpretative Character](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/InterpretativeCharacter): Due to her many appearances in spinoffs, she has been portrayed with various classes such as a summoner in *Final Fantasy Legends II*, an Onion Knight in *Brave Exvius* (though, as a separate unit from Refia normally) and a monk in *Record Keeper*. That said, she usually uses a class from the White Mage line or a support class.

[In the Hood](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/InTheHood): She's the only Light Warrior to wear the White Mage hood and one of two to wear the Devout hood (Arc being the other). Her Freelancer/normal outfit also gains a hood after her second promotion in *Brave Exvius*.

[Missing Main Character](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/MissingMainCharacter): Refia is the only member of the four to temporarily leave the party in the final game  <sup>note </sup>  The unused text, however, shows that Arc and Alus were meant to temporarily leave during the Saronia plotline.  and does so twice: After her initial recruitment, Refia refuses to enter Kazus during the ghost crisis out of fear of facing her father. After the situation is resolved, Takka takes her home and she stays there until Cid asks Takka to make a ram for his airship. Afterwards, she goes to the airship, where she permanently rejoins the party.

[Platonic Life-Partners](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/PlatonicLifePartners): She forms a close friendship with Desch, but she also bonds with his girlfriend immediately and tells him off sternly for not treating her better.
[Playing with Fire](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/PlayingWithFire): Her main element in *Final Fantasy Record Keeper* is fire.
[Proper Tights with a Skirt](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/ProperTightsWithASkirt): Tights or leggings.

[Related in the Adaptation](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/RelatedInTheAdaptation): In *World of Final Fantasy*, Refia is Takka's niece as opposed to his adopted daughter. The Bahamutian soldier possessing his body confirms that they are related by blood as well.

[The Runaway](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/TheRunaway): She dodged the Djinn's curse as a result of having ran away from her father to avoid training and her description when she's introduced makes it clear that this is not the first time this has happened. She later runs away *again* to permanently rejoin the party after making the airship ram, though Takka understands.
[The Smurfette Principle](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/TheSmurfettePrinciple): The only ([permanent](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/GuestStarPartyMember)) girl in the group.

[Suddenly Voiced](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/SuddenlyVoiced): As of *[World of Final Fantasy](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/VideoGame/WorldOfFinalFantasy)* she is the only one of the four DS characters to actually have an audible voice.

[Suspiciously Specific Denial](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/SuspiciouslySpecificDenial): In the unused dialogue, this is her tactic when she inadvertedly reveals to Sara that the mythril ring used to be hers.

tropeName: This Looks Like a Job for Aquaman
tropeNotes: [This Looks Like a Job for Aquaman](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/ThisLooksLikeAJobForAquaman): [Subverted](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/Subverted). Luneth and Arc initially assume that, as a blacksmith's apprentice, Refia could make a mythril ring they could use to end the curse. However, Refia admits that she's not at that skill level due to her disinterest in smithing, and instead points the party in the direction of Castle Sasune.

[Tomboy with a Girly Streak](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/TomboyWithAGirlyStreak): Slightly inevitable when you're adopted by a blacksmith. Her clothes are frilly while being practical, though, and she takes an interest in Salina's romantic problems.

[Team Mom](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/TeamMom): It happens when you're the Light of Affection. She both looks after them and tells them off when they misbehave. Unei directly notes this in *Memory Of Heroes*, although Refia is disgusted by the comparison.
[True Blue Femininity](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/TrueBlueFemininity): Her default outfit and job class color are blue and she's the female of the group.
[White Mage](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/WhiteMage): She is portrayed as one in the opening, artwork and in *[Final Fantasy Brave Exvius](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/VideoGame/FinalFantasyBraveExvius)*.

tropeName: Why Did It Have to Be Snakes?
tropeNotes:
[Why Did It Have to Be Snakes?](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/WhyDidItHaveToBeSnakes): She *hates* toads, as she is all too open about expressing whenever the need to transform into them arises. Becomes rather funny if *she* happens to be the mage who has to cast the spell. When it turns out that the Warriors of Light have to do it *again* later on, she just kinda hangs her head in resignation. Poor girl.
QUOTE  ***Refia:**** Toads!? I hate toads! Don't turn me into one!*

[Adaptation Personality Change](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/AdaptationPersonalityChange): Twofold in *Memory of Heroes*: First, while generally remaining stoic, he displays [more emotion](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/NotSoStoic) throughout the adaptation. Secondly, he's [far snarkier](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/AdaptationalJerkAss) here than in other portrayals, to the point of not being above insulting Luneth.

[Agent Scully](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/AgentScully): He has a tendency to be skeptical such as expressing disbelief at Desch's memories of why the continent is floating, as well as the idea of the floating continent itself.

[Aloof Ally](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/AloofAlly): Downplayed in the final game, but Ingus is shown at rare moments to exhibit annoyance or frustration at the rest of the group's antics. This is most apparent in the unused text for the Amur Sewers where he admits that he finds them too "soft" to have been chosen by the crystals. He does change his stance after encountering the Four Old Men.

[Amputation Stops Spread](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/AmputationStopsSpread): In *Memory Of Heroes*, as his arm [turns to stone](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/TakenForGranite) thanks to Medusa's bite, Ingus elects to use his knife to shatter the arm and use Refia's Cure magic to regrow it.
[Anime Hair](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/AnimeHair): It looks like he stood with his back to a high-powered fan and applied hairspray.

[Ascended Extra](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/AscendedExtra): Unlike the other new Warriors of Light, he actually *is* present in the original version of the game... as a nameless Sasune soldier who managed to avoid being turned into a ghost due to being away on a mission when the Djinn's curse fell upon the castle. The location in which he's encountered and the means by which he avoided said curse (although with different reasoning) were both retained in the 3D version.

[Badass Cape](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/BadassCape): After his initial promotion in *Brave Exvius*, as a result of taking on Red Mage characteristics, Ingus gets a cape for his Freelancer/Normal outfit. He also sports one in several of his home game's job classes.
[Big Brother Mentor](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/BigBrotherMentor): Towards Luneth and Arc especially. In the unused text, he leans closer to a [Team Dad](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/TeamDad).
[Bodyguard Crush](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/BodyguardCrush): There is a small love story between him and Princess Sara.

[Bullying a Dragon](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/BullyingADragon): He and Luneth were willing to stand their ground against Bahamut when it initially appears. It takes Desch's emphasis on how [dangerous](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/HopelessBossFight) it is for them to start running.

[Casting a Shadow](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/CastingAShadow): He's one of the characters capable of using the "Fell Sword" technique in *Pictlogica Final Fantasy* and unused text hints that he was initially raised in the Dark Knight village of Falgabard, though whether or not he actually becomes a dark knight is up to the player. He also takes up the position of Dark Knight in *Memory of Heroes*, though we only see it around the time of Doga and Unei's fight. [Inverted](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/InvertedTrope) in *Record Keeper* where he is a Knight with access to Holy abilities and White Magic.

[Chick Magnet](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/ChickMagnet): [Downplayed](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/Downplayed): There's obviously Sara, but unused text implies that there is a handmaid who secretly pines for him and the dancer in Ur tries to kiss him (though Sara [has none of that](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/ClingyJealousGirl)).

[Childhood Home Rediscovery](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/ChildhoodHomeRediscovery): In the unused text, Ingus experiences a wave of nostalgia upon arriving in Falgabard, but he doesn't explicitly remember anything and his [skeptic nature](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/AgentScully) causes him to resist the party's theories that he grew up there. Even so, he eventually opens to the idea and [expresses a desire to return](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/RediscoveringRootsTrip).
[Colour-Coded for Your Convenience](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/ColourCodedForYourConvenience): Red, derived from his gambeson.

[Consummate Professional](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/ConsummateProfessional): His upbringing as a soldier means that he's significantly more serious and no-nonsense than the rest of the Warriors of Light. This is highlighted mostly in his views of the Four Old Men in Amur, but some scenes in the unused text imply that this attitude extends towards his teammates to a certain extent.

[Cryptic Background Reference](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/CrypticBackgroundReference): While all four light warriors have a [Mysterious Past](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/MysteriousPast), unused text for the game only directly touches upon his; In the Cave of The Circle, Doga compares his eyes to those of a dark blade wielder and in Falgabard and the Cave of Shadows (both areas heavily associated with classes that wield dark blades) Ingus expresses familiarity with the area upon arriving.
[Deadpan Snarker](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/DeadpanSnarker): In *Memory of Heroes*, usually directed at Luneth.
[Dishing Out Dirt](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/DishingOutDirt): Earth is his main element in *[Final Fantasy Record Keeper](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/VideoGame/FinalFantasyRecordKeeper)*.
[Everything's Sparkly with Jewelry](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/EverythingsSparklyWithJewelry): His large jade pendant, which appears on many of his job classes' outfit.
[Giant Poofy Sleeves](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/GiantPoofySleeves): Okay, so they're not *that* giant, but they are still very poofy.

[Guest Fighter](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/GuestFighter): He appears in *Pictlogica Final Fantasy*, *Final Fantasy Airbourne Brigade*, *Final Fantasy Record Keeper* and *Final Fantasy Brave Exivus*. Additionally, Onion Knight's DLC costume in *Dissidia 012 (Duodecim)* is based specifically on his outfits (though, in contrast with Luneth's costume, Ingus is not mentioned in the name or description of the DLC pack in the Japanese version of the game.)

tropeName: Hair of Gold, Heart of Gold
tropeNotes: [Hair of Gold, Heart of Gold](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/HairOfGoldHeartOfGold): He's the traditional noble knight in shining armour.

[Heroic Self-Deprecation](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/HeroicSelfDeprecation): It's implied that he feels powerless when fighting on his own. This aspect is most apparent in the unused text but it's still alluded to in a conversation with Sara, his Trust Mastery quote in *Brave Exvius* and in [Easter Egg](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/EasterEgg) dialogue in *Record Keeper* at the end of the Nemesis battle in the Hall of the Beyond if [Y'shtola](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/VideoGame/FinalFantasyXIV) and [Ramza](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/VideoGame/FinalFantasyTactics) are in the party.

[Humble Hero](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/HumbleHero): He acknowledges that his strength comes from his allies. This is more zigzagged in the unused text where certain moments do portray him in a more arrogant light, something he comes to acknowledge.
[Icy Blue Eyes](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/IcyBlueEyes): While harder to tell on his CG model, his in-game model has gray-blue eyes, befitting his serious nature.
[Knightly Sword and Shield](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/KnightlySwordAndShield): His relics in *Record Keeper* generally invoke this, mostly being swords and shields.

[Lady and Knight](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/LadyAndKnight): White Knight to Sara's Bright Lady. He acts like a [Knight in Shining Armor](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/KnightInShiningArmor) while he's away from Sasune, too.

[The Lancer](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/TheLancer): He's more experienced and mature than Luneth and the others, being an actual knight rather than some village kid. This is subtly reflected in that he is level 4 when he joins the party, whereas Arc and Refia join at Level 3.

[Magic Knight](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/MagicKnight): In the opening FMV, Ingus ignites his sword and uses it to cast a spell with Arc against the behemoth. He also enchants his sword for his special moves in both Record Keeper and Brave Exvius, though Earth elemental for former and merely swinging it with both hands for the latter.

[Parental Abandonment](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/ParentalAbandonment): Unlike the other three orphans, Ingus is not shown to have foster parents and it is implied that the king is the closest he has to one. *Memory of Heroes* upgrades this to an [Ambiguously Absent Parent](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/AmbiguouslyAbsentParent), as it is mentioned in passing that he is the adopted son of one of the soldiers, but is otherwise not elaborated on further than that.
[Perpetual Frowner](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/PerpetualFrowner): Outside of a few moments of the opening FMV, he usually has frown on his face.  (SPOILER)  Until the ending.
[The Quiet One](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/TheQuietOne): He's not as chatty as the other three. That usually means what he does say is serious.

[Rebel Relaxation](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/RebelRelaxation): He takes this pose upon winning a battle, adding in a [Fist Pump](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/FistPump) during a level up. *Brave Exvius* tweaks it to a simple [Badass Arm-Fold](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/BadassArmFold).

[Red Mage](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/RedMage): In the opening, artwork and *[Final Fantasy Brave Exvius](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/VideoGame/FinalFantasyBraveExvius)*. Bonus points for the area you meet him in (Castle Sasune) endorsing Red Mages.
[The Reliable One](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/TheReliableOne): He has a very solid and imperturbable manner.
[Ship Tease](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/ShipTease): He has plenty with Princess Sara.

[Spell Blade](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/SpellBlade): As mentioned, he does this in the intro FMV and his Limit Break in *Brave Exivus*. [Zigzagged](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/Zigzagged) in *Record Keeper* where, although he does something similar in his Soul Break animations, Ingus can't actually use Spellblade abilities.

[The Spock](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/TheSpock): Most apparent in *Memory of Heroes* right before the fight against [Doga and Unei](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/FightingYourFriend), where he's this role to Luneth's [The McCoy](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/TheMcCoy): While Luneth gets angry at him for being ready to kill Doga and Unei, Ingus states that he is agreeing with Doga and simply [doing what he must](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/IDidWhatIHadToDo).

[The Stoic](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/TheStoic): While he's not necessarily cold, he's more standoffish than the other three, and his character animations are far more reserved. For one thing, he's the only one who doesn't jump when he levels up.

[Sugar-and-Ice Personality](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/SugarAndIcePersonality): Sugar around Princess Sara and, to a lesser extent, his friends. Otherwise he acts like [The Stoic](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/TheStoic).

[Team Dad](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/TeamDad): It's more evident in the unused text, where he's stricter and more no-nonsense, while also showing more care and concern to his fellow light warriors. Actually brought up at one point in the unused Saronia lines where, during a rant, Arc angrily states that Ingus isn't his parent/guardian.

[Vague Age](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/VagueAge):
    - Much like Luneth, his age doesn't come up in-game nor in unused text, with the closest thing to a hint being that he's 15 years old at minimum note  In the unused text for Falgabard, Ingus mentions that he's served Sasune since age four. Cid's story places the airship crash at "more than 10 years ago", although [the english version translates that as "10 years ago" exactly](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/Blooper). . He's implied to be older than the others, both in the way he acts and the fact that he has [Ship Tease](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/ShipTease) with Sara who's confirmed to be 21. - ''Brave Exvius calls Ingus a "young man" in his description, like Desch and unlike Luneth, Arc and Onion Knight, all of whom are referred to with "young boy".
[Vitriolic Best Buds](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/VitriolicBestBuds): With Luneth in *Memory of Heroes* and implied in the opening movie. The actual game doesn't really feature it though.
[Was Too Hard on Him](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/WasTooHardOnHim): He feels this way after Arc leaves the party in the unused text for Saronia.

[When She Smiles](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/WhenSheSmiles): One of the few, if only, moments in the game (outside of the intro FMV) where Ingus smiles is  (SPOILER) during the ending when Princess Sara asks to stay with the him longer instead of being sent back to the castle .
[Adaptational Badass](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/AdaptationalBadass): In *Brave Exivus*, she's finally given the chance to fully fight alongside others and to go on adventures.

[Adaptational Wimp](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/AdaptationalWimp): Unlike the game where she's enroute to seal the Djinn away, she's trapped in her tower *by* the Djinn in the manga and while she does prepare to face off against him at one point in the fight, she never gets the chance to do so. In fairness, the Djinn himself is under [the opposite trope](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/AdaptationalBadass).
[Blow You Away](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/BlowYouAway): She can cast the Aero spell and her ability set in *Brave Exvius* is primarily themed around wind.
[The Cameo](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/TheCameo): She appears in the Record Dungeons in *Final Fantasy Record Keeper*, but has yet to be playable.
[Clingy Jealous Girl](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/ClingyJealousGirl): She shows signs of being one during the ending, when a dancer tries to kiss Ingus.

[Damsel in Distress](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/DamselInDistress):
    - Subverted. Everyone *assumes* that she's been kidnapped by the Djinn, because she and the ring are gone. You find her in his lair, on her own and quite un-kidnapped, having decided to go and seal him herself. - Played straight in the manga where she's initially trapped in her room by the Djinn.
[Guest Fighter](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/GuestFighter): She appears in *[Final Fantasy Brave Exvius](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/VideoGame/FinalFantasyBraveExvius)* as a potential vision.

tropeName: Hair of Gold, Heart of Gold
tropeNotes: [Hair of Gold, Heart of Gold](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/HairOfGoldHeartOfGold): The beautiful and noble princess of Sasune obviously bears the right appearance.
[Healing Hands](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/HealingHands): She may occasionally use a Cure spell and she learns White Magic abilities in *Brave Exvius*.
[Lady and Knight](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/LadyAndKnight): Bright Lady to Ingus's White Knight.
[Magic Staff](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/MagicStaff): She uses a scepter in *Brave Exvius*, both for casting magic and for physical attacks.
[Missing Mom](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/MissingMom): While the king of Sasune is present, the queen is nowhere to be seen.  (SPOILER) The Mognet questline in the 3D version heavily implies she is dead.

[Mythology Gag](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/MythologyGag): The [second](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/VideoGame/FinalFantasyI) [of](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/VideoGame/FinalFantasyIII) [four](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/VideoGame/FinalFantasyIX) [Princess](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/VideoGame/FinalFantasyDimensions) [Sara(h)s](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/InconsistentSpelling).

[Older Than They Look](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/OlderThanTheyLook): Sara is 21, but the 3D version's artstyle doesn't make that entirely clear (which isn't helped with Ingus' [Vague Age](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/VagueAge)). [Averted](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/Averted) elsewhere such as in her artwork or the manga.

[Rich Boredom](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/RichBoredom): While she understands *why* she can't go, she makes it clear that she would wishes she could accompany the Warriors of Light on their quest. This is especially apparent in the DS version, where one of her Mognet letters directly [discusses](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/DiscussedTrope) this trope.
[Ring of Power](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/RingOfPower): Her Mythril Ring will seal the Djinn.
[Royals Who Actually Do Something](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/RoyalsWhoActuallyDoSomething): Though she admits to being nervous, she doesn't hesitate to confront the danger to her kingdom.
[Ship Tease](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/ShipTease): She clearly has a thing for Ingus in the DS version and her lines in *Brave Exvius*.

[Stripperiffic](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/Stripperiffic):
    - In the her Amano artwork, which is the basis for her design in the DS version. Downplayed in that she's well-covered everywhere else, but her outfit still shows her cleavage and her belly button. - Played straight in the manga which combines her Famicom leotard with the top half of her Amano outfit.

[Tomboy Princess](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/TomboyPrincess): Supplementary material suggests that she's more of a tomboy than she may seem. This can be seen in some of her mannerisms, both in the games and in the *Memory of Heroes* novel.

[Tragic Keepsake](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/TragicKeepsake): In the DS version's Mognet sidequest, this is why she is desperate to have her pendant fixed:  (SPOILER) It used to belong to [her mother](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/MissingMom) .
[True Companions](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/TrueCompanions): With the Warriors of Light in general in the Famicom game and Ingus in particular in the 3D version.
[Warrior Princess](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/WarriorPrincess): The first of many for this series. When the Djinn curses her kingdom, she initially goes alone to seal him away.

[White Mage](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/WhiteMage): Uses Cure and Aero <sup>note </sup>  classed as White Magic in this game  when she helps in battle. Downplayed in *Brave Exvius* where she is classified as a Princess, though she still has plenty of white magic abilities.

[Adaptation Origin Connection](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/AdaptationOriginConnection): In the 3D version,  (SPOILER) it's revealed that Cid was carrying passengers on his airship as the flood of darkness hit. The resulting crash is only survived by himself and the four children that would go on to become the Warriors of Light. By contrast, the Famicom version gives no indication that Cid used to live on the surface.

[Ascended Extra](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/AscendedExtra):
    - In the 3D version, (SPOILER) He is significantly important to the backstory of the four orphans, namely being the reason why they are on the floating continent to begin with. - For much of the manga, he pilots the party's [Global Airship](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/GlobalAirship).

[Chekhov's Gunman](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/ChekhovsGunman): Cid's expertise with airships comes in handy when the party needs to upgrade their boat.  (SPOILER) And there's his role in the four orphans backstory in the 3D version.

[Cool Airship](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/CoolAirship):
    - He owns an airship by the time the game starts, although it's arguably a [Subversion](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/Subversion) as it's the least impressive of the airships the party will use over the course of the game. - The manga interprets Cid's airship as a an fantastical sailboat, rather than the galleon of the games.
[Cool Old Guy](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/CoolOldGuy): He' a lively old man who builds airships.
[Cool Shades](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/CoolShades): He also has a pair of goggles sitting on his hat.

[Cryptic Background Reference](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/CrypticBackgroundReference):
    - In the original Famicom game, talking to Cid after he upgrades the boat has him mention that he used to make airships for King Argus. The 3D version transfers the dialogue to a soldier in Castle Argus, who instead says that Cid and the king are old friends who used to do airship research. - (SPOILER) In the 3D version, the Saronia engineers mention a "genius engineer" of Saronia who resurrected the Nautilus and mentions that said inventor was on an airship when the Flood of Darkness hit before wondering what happened to him. These seem to point to Cid being that engineer. The english version states that Cid "invented" the Nautilus and calls him an engineer of the "Saronia of Old", [which raises some questions.](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/DubInducedPlotHole)
[The Engineer](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/TheEngineer): He owns an airship and helps to upgrade the Enterprise into an airship.  (SPOILER) An NPC in Saronia also hints that he resurrected the Nautilus.
[Guest Fighter](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/GuestFighter): He appears as a party member in the *[Theatrhythm Final Fantasy](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/VideoGame/TheatrhythmFinalFantasy)* series.
[Happily Married](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/HappilyMarried): To his wife, who is known as "Mrs. Cid" rather than Haze for some reason.
[Helicopter Pack](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/HelicopterPack): In the manga, his backpack has a propeller that allows it to junction as a flight device.
[Legacy Character](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/LegacyCharacter): There's an old guy named Cid and big shocker, he owns an airship. Go figure.
[Playing with Fire](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/PlayingWithFire): In the 3D version, he can cast Fira to attack enemies.

[True Companions](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/TrueCompanions): With the Warriors of Light in general in the original and the 3D version (though  (SPOILER) when Doga summons everyone else to break the Curse of the Five Wyrms, Cid specifically mentions Luneth ).

[Adaptation Origin Connection](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/AdaptationOriginConnection): A subtle case that only comes up once [Fridge Logic](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/FridgeLogic) sets in: (SPOILER) The 2D version's Books of Owen were set long before the events of the game and reveal that Desch was frozen right during the Wrath of Light. The 3D version's Books of Owen, on the other hand are implied to have been written somewhat recently, ending as Owen and Desch leave for "the test site"; Implied to be what would become the Floating Continent. Thus, Desch being frozen in order to guard the Tower of Owen is a direct result of Xande unleashing the flood of darkness.

[Adaptational Badass](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/AdaptationalBadass):
    - [Ziggzagged](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/ZigzaggedTrope) in the manga. On one hand, he doesn't use magic nor his sword. On the other, he's able to *[chop down a tree barehanded](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/GoodOldFisticuffs)*, so he doesn't really need them. - *Memory of Heroes* skips the Nepto Shrine by revealing that Desch had previously helped the vikings out of a situation of their own. While [details aren't given](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/NoodleIncident), one with knowledge of the games is left to assume that the situation in question was the Nepto Shrine scenario.

[Adaptational Villainy](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/AdaptationalVillainy): Initially in the manga, Desch appears to be villainous, commanding flocks of birds to attack the protagonists as well as brainwashing people, including [Muuchi](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/TheHero). However, it's later [Subverted](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/Subverted) when it is revealed that he himself was brainwashed by a monster and he promptly begins acting more like his game counterpart.

[Black Mage](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/BlackMage): His class in *[Final Fantasy Record Keeper](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/VideoGame/FinalFantasyRecordKeeper)*, deriving from his use of the Thundara spell when acting as a guest in the party.
[Brainwashed and Crazy](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/BrainwashedAndCrazy): He's under the influence of a monster in the manga and can, in turn, use his birds to brainwash others, including Muuchi.

[Cool Sword](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/CoolSword): Desch is shown to have a curved sword in his Amano artwork (and implied in dialogue, for the *Pixel Remaster*, at least) and he actually uses it for his physical attacks in the 3D version. Notably, unlike Cid who uses a generic hammer, Desch wields a distinct sword that only he can use; It would go on to become his signature weapon in later appearances  <sup>note </sup>  While Desch's sword *can* be hacked into the item menu via a cheat device, it is impossible to actually equip it. .

[Costume Evolution](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/CostumeEvolution): His outfit has been tweaked numerous times:
    - The original Amano artwork had him in a jumpsuit with pads on his shoulder and brown hair. This appearance is the basis for his design in *Opera Omnia*. Additionally, the Famicom version, presumably due to a limited palette, makes his outfit green instead of the traditional purple. - The manga translated the jumpsuit as a robe and gave Desch a hat. He gets a different outfit and a different hat upon being freed from his brainwashing. - The 3D version translates his jumpsuit as a coat, gives him blue-ish hair and adds a strange device to his left shoulder, presumably to allude to his status as a [Gadgeteer Genius](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/GadgeteerGenius).

[Disney Death](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/DisneyDeath): Desch throws himself into the boiler of the Tower of Owen, with his fate being ambiguous at best and clearly dead at worst.  (SPOILER) When Doga calls the Warriors of Lights' companions, he arrives just in time for Desch to climb back up, having narrowly fixed the tower.

[Feathered Fiend](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/FeatheredFiend): In the manga, he has the ability to command birds, which he uses to attack the Warriors of Light. [Subverted](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/Subverted) when he returns to normal as he's shown to retain the ability.

[Gadgeteer Genius](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/GadgeteerGenius):  (SPOILER) Along with the information that he and his father are [Older Than They Look](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/OlderThanHeLooks), Saronia Library also provides some examples of their trivial inventions other than the tower, such as three of the four [Global Airships](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/GlobalAirship) that the party use in the course of [Final Fantasy III](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/VideoGame/FinalFantasyIII) .
[Good Old Fisticuffs](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/GoodOldFisticuffs): He fights with his fists in the manga, unlike in the 3D version.

[Guest Fighter](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/GuestFighter): He appears in not only *[Final Fantasy Record Keeper](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/VideoGame/FinalFantasyRecordKeeper)*, but *[Final Fantasy Brave Exvius](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/VideoGame/FinalFantasyBraveExvius)* and *[Dissidia Final Fantasy: Opera Omnia](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/VideoGame/DissidiaFinalFantasyOperaOmnia)* as well.

[Handsome Lech](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/HandsomeLech):
    - The first thing he says after they gain the Enterprise? That now they can meet different girls from different places, no matter the fact that he has a sick girlfriend that falls sick in the first place because he leaves her village. Refia has to keep him in line. - *Record Keeper* actually makes this a mechanic: Specifically, Desch's Awakening is one of the few that gets stronger depending on how many girls are on the team. - *Opera Omnia* once more touches upon this aspect in his character event. Onion Knight teases him by threatening to tell Salina, and almost tells the rest of the party before Desch backs down.

[Heroic Sacrifice](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/HeroicSacrifice):
    - He throws himself into the boiler of the Tower of Owen in order to fix it. (SPOILER) [He doesn't die, however.](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/UnexplainedRecovery) - In the manga, he fuses with the Queen Tree to restore the surface world. Unlike his game counterpart however, (SPOILER) he doesn't come back .

[Laser-Guided Amnesia](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/LaserGuidedAmnesia): Can't remember anything but his name.  (SPOILER) Later revealed to be [The Fog of Ages](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/TheFogOfAges); his extended hibernation messed up his memories.
[Magic Knight](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/MagicKnight): He uses either a sword or a Thunder spell when he appears in battle.

[Older Than He Looks](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/OlderThanHeLooks): The more he climbs the Tower of Owen, the more memories he unlocks; including the memories that he was the one who built the tower and the reason why. We only hear a brief explanation, but Saronia Library gives the more detailed one.  (SPOILER) Desch and his father belonged to the Ancients, a race that went into hiding after their actions caused the Flood of Light 1000 years ago. They created the tower to separate the Crystal of Wind and Fire along with the whole [Floating Continent](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/FloatingContinent) to lessen the Flood and to give the Warriors of Darkness their chance to stop it altogether.

[The Pollyanna](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/ThePollyanna): He doesn't let his amnesia keep him down and is usually jovial while he's with the party.  (SPOILER)  It's only once he starts to remember his duty as the guardian of the Tower of Owen that he begins to get serious.

[Sailor's Ponytail](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/SailorsPonytail): Desch is an adventurous vagabond and has a ponytail to aid the image. It actually seems to be one of the more consistent aspects of his design.

[Shock and Awe](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/ShockAndAwe): He can potentially cast Thundara when he appears in battle and as a result, this is his main element in *[Final Fantasy Record Keeper](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/VideoGame/FinalFantasyRecordKeeper)* and *[Dissidia Final Fantasy: Opera Omnia](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/VideoGame/DissidiaFinalFantasyOperaOmnia)*.
[Suddenly Voiced](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/SuddenlyVoiced): *Opera Omnia* is the first time he has had a (Japanese) voice.
[True Companions](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/TrueCompanions): With the Warriors of Light in general in the Famicom version, Refia in particular in the 3D version and with Onion Knight in *Opera Omnia*.
[Walking Shirtless Scene](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/WalkingShirtlessScene): In the manga, during a fight with the Warriors of Light, Desch's shirt rips in two as he proceeds to give them a beat down.

[You Don't Look Like You](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/YouDontLookLikeYou):
    - Desch's character design in the manga is *very* different from the games, even after he's rescued. - Amano's [alternative design](https://vignette.wikia.nocookie.net/finalfantasy/images/2/2a/Hunter.jpg/revision/latest?cb=20120604132308) for Desch is unrecognizable, even compared to the manga.
[Adapted Out](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/AdaptedOut): She does not appear in the manga, though Alus' manga counterpart has similar elements to her.
[Dub Name Change](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/DubNameChange): From Elia to Aria.
[Force Field](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/ForceField): She Has a Protect spell.

[Guest Fighter](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/GuestFighter):
    - She appears as a party member in *[Final Fantasy Record Keeper](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/VideoGame/FinalFantasyRecordKeeper)*. - She appears as a potential vision in *[Final Fantasy Brave Exvius](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/VideoGame/FinalFantasyBraveExvius)*.

tropeName: Hair of Gold, Heart of Gold
tropeNotes: [Hair of Gold, Heart of Gold](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/HairOfGoldHeartOfGold): Sweet, slightly ethereal, pure-hearted priestess who has flowing golden hair.
[Healing Hands](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/HealingHands): She can cast a Cure Spell.

[Last of Her Kind](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/LastOfHerKind):  (SPOILER) There are subtle hints that implied the Maidens of Water were from a large tribe, but slowly began dying out to prevent the Flood of Darkness from consuming the world while waiting for [The Chosen One](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/TheChosenOne), and they still have to keep surviving because they are the only ones who can break the Crystal Shard's seal. Aria is the last one of them, and by the time [The Chosen Ones](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/TheChosenOne) finally come, she's already dying and bed-ridden.
[Leitmotif](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/Leitmotif): She's notable for being the first character in a Final Fantasy game to have her own theme music.
[Making a Splash](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/MakingASplash): Her method of attacking in *Brave Exvius* is to create a wave of water.
[Mysterious Waif](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/MysteriousWaif): She seems a bit delicate and acts a bit mystical, referring to the "light" the heroes have in them.
[Sacrificial Lamb](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/SacrificialLamb):  (SPOILER) She leaves the party by dying.

[Taking the Bullet](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/TakingTheBullet):  (SPOILER) She takes a poison arrow meant for the party—specifically for Luneth in the 3D version. There's a boss battle and an earthquake immediately after, so they can't save her in the chaos.
[White Mage](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/WhiteMage): Both of her spells are White Magic (Protect and Cura). She also takes this role in *Record Keeper*. Fittingly, she has a long white dress.

[Adaptational Wimp](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/AdaptationalWimp): Zigzagged; *Memory of Heroes* doesn't have him contribute to the fight against Garuda like he can do so in the 3D version (not that [the warriors need it](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/AnticlimaxBoss)), but he begins to draw his sword against the ruffians mocking him in the tavern, implying he can fight to some degree.

[Age Lift](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/AgeLift): He seems to be a teenager in the manga rather than a child like in the game. Either that or he's [Younger Than He Looks](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/YoungerThanHeLooks).

[All-Encompassing Mantle](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/AllEncompassingMantle): Especially during [his entrance](https://64.media.tumblr.com/65ee1705bc74b74f0b15ada4e7233b12/07604a8e97440593-bc/s1280x1920/d4018ab768331eeab448f15f4d4efb955af16ffb.jpg)◊ in the manga.
[Bad Ass Long Robe](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/BadAssLongRobe): "Badass" maybe not, but Alus does wear a large mantle in his Amano artwork and the manga. The 3D version changes it to a simpler cape.
[Battle Boomerang](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/BattleBoomerang): His weapon, which can be seen on his back.
[Blow You Away](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/BlowYouAway): He can cast Aero spell.

[The Cameo](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/TheCameo): In *Final Fantasy Record Keeper* though much more indirectly than Sara: The Famicom gameplay videos seen in Arc's *Heavenly Rains* soul break are from the Saronia stretch of the game; namely, while Alus is in the party.
[A Child Shall Lead Them](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/AChildShallLeadThem):  (SPOILER) He ascends the throne after his father's death.

[Composite Character](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/CompositeCharacter): In the manga, he retains his role of being the prince of Solados, but him being a guide to the surface for the Warriors of Light, him being the [Last of His Kind](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/LastOfHisKind),  (SPOILER)  and his apparent death  make him closer to Aria than to his game counterpart.
[Confusion Fu](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/ConfusionFu): He may cast the Confuse spell during battle.
[Cool Sword](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/CoolSword): In his Amano artwork only, although *Memory of Heroes* shows he has one anyway.

[Depending on the Artist](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/DependingOnTheArtist): Not quite to Desch's extremes, but still very noticeable:
    - The 2D versions depicts Alus as wearing a large coat with a crown (tilted in his portrait sprite) and, due to the Famicom's limited palette, a red and white color scheme. The *Pixel Remaster* gives Alus a color palette in line with his other appearances, except for his hair now being blonde. - The Amano artwork gives Alus purple clothes with a orange mantle, a sheath or boomerang on his back and white hair. Alus' skintone is also noticeably colored compared to other characters Amano draws. - The 3D version takes cues from Amano's design, although it replaces the mantle with a simple cape and more clearly portrays the thing on his back as a boomerang. - Alus wears a very different outfit in the manga, both in his flashback and in the present, on top of the apparent [Age Lift](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/AgeLift). While he does keep his mantle, the manga changes Alus' overall color scheme to red (mantle), blue (clothes) and brown ([hair](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/AdaptationDyeJob)). The thing on his back is also more clearly shown to be a sheath for some kind of knife.
[The Exile](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/TheExile): You meet him being bullied because his father had banished him and stripped him of his title, and nobody thinks he's the real prince.

[Last of His Kind](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/LastOfHisKind): In the manga, he's the only remaining citizen of [Solados](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/AdaptationalNameChange) after its destruction.  (SPOILER)  This does not last either.
[Missing Mom](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/MissingMom): Alus' mother is never brought up during the main Saronia plotline. It's only by talking to an NPC afterwards that it is learned that she is dead.
[The Power of Love](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/ThePowerOfLove):  (SPOILER) The only thing that prevents King Gorn from killing his own son.

[Royals Who Actually Do Something](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/RoyalsWhoActuallyDoSomething): Although he's a bit lost for what to do after his banishment, he quickly takes the opportunity to try and help his father.

[True Companions](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/TrueCompanions): With the Warriors of Light in general in the Famicom version and Arc in particular in the 3D version. This is alluded to both in *Record Keeper* with Arc's *Heavenly Rains* soul break and in *Brave Exvius* via one of Black Mage Arc's passives.
[White Mage](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/WhiteMage): He uses the Confuse and Aero spells, when appearing in battle.

[Wise Beyond Their Years](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/WiseBeyondTheirYears): Despite being 10, he takes the affairs of his kingdom seriously.  (SPOILER)  When he ascends the throne after his father's death, he seems to fit comfortably into role of king.

[The Wise Prince](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/TheWisePrince): He's deeply troubled by his father's behavior and where it will lead the kingdom.  (SPOILER)  After his father's death, he becomes [The Good King](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/TheGoodKing).

[Adaptational Attractiveness](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/AdaptationalAttractiveness): Both of them in the manga. Downplayed for Doga who merely looks younger, played straight for Unei who has her game appearance for all of one page before transforming into her [Hotter and Sexier](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/HotterAndSexier) younger design.
[The Archmage](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/TheArchmage): Doga is the most powerful mage in the world, courtesy of Noah.

[Big Fancy House](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/BigFancyHouse): Doga owns a manor which is staffed entirely by his moogles.  (SPOILER) It also has a grotto where Doga and Unei go to create the key to Eureka.  *Memory of Heroes* suggests that it used to be Noah's.

[Big Good](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/BigGood):
    - They act as one for the final leg of the story, guiding the Light Warriors to their final battle with Xande and aiding them in various ways. - In the album *Final Fantasy III: Eternal Legend of the Wind*, Doga is said to be the voice of the wind, guiding the Warriors of Light in their journey.
[Black Mage](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/BlackMage): Doga sticks to black magic when he joins the party.
[Cool Old Guy](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/CoolOldGuy): Doga.  (SPOILER)  Emphasis on "old"
[Cool Old Lady](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/CoolOldLady): Unei shoves her way into the party and casually detonates boulders.

[Dream Walker](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/DreamWalker): Noah gave Unei power of the dreamscape, which is implied to involve this. The 3D version outright confirms it by having her visit Luneth while he is unconscious.
[Dual Boss](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/DualBoss):  (SPOILER) They force the party to fight them in succession .
[Early-Bird Cameo](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/EarlyBirdCameo): Unei appears to the party after the fight with Kraken, just before they wake up in the restored surface world.

[Evil Knockoff](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/EvilKnockoff):  (SPOILER)  [Clones of their boss forms](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/DegradedBoss) populate the Ancients Maze (Unei) and the Crystal Tower (Doga), both on their own or summoned by enemies.
[Familiar](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/Familiar): Unei's parrot is implied to be one. It even speaks!
[Guest Fighter](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/GuestFighter): Both of them appear as potential visions in *Brave Exvius*.
[Holy Hand Grenade](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/HolyHandGrenade): Unei uses Holy.
[Inconsistent Spelling](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/InconsistentSpelling): "Doga" and "Unei" is sometimes romanized as "Dorga" and "Une".
[I Was Quite a Looker](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/IWasQuiteALooker): Both of them in manga, but especially [Unei](http://finalfantasy.wikia.com/wiki/File:FFIII_Manga_Dogo_and_Unei_Young.jpg)◊.

[Leitmotif](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/Leitmotif): One that has several names, but is usually referred to as *Doga and Unei* or *Let Me Know The Truth*. It plays in areas related to them and makes a few recurring appearances throughout the series, particularly for their counterparts in *[Final Fantasy XIV](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/VideoGame/FinalFantasyXIV)*. The "Eternal Legend of the Wind" album adds lyrics to it, as part of the song "Their Spiritual Leader".

[Mythology Gag](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/MythologyGag): Unei's younger appearance in the manga is based on [an unused Amano design for her.](http://vignette1.wikia.nocookie.net/finalfantasy/images/f/f5/FFIII_Unei_Amano_%28alternate%29.jpg/revision/latest?cb=20120603014623)
[Never Mess with Granny](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/NeverMessWithGranny): Unei. When Luneth tries to suggest that she take it easy, she slaps him down in short order.
[One-Winged Angel](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/OneWingedAngel): Both of them take on monstrous forms when they fight the Warriors.
[Playing with Fire](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/PlayingWithFire): Doga casts Flare and Firaga.

[Sink or Swim Mentor](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/SinkOrSwimMentor):  (SPOILER) They're fighting to *kill* the party in the dual boss fight , and there's no break to heal in between. But if the Warriors of Light can't manage that, there's no way they'd be able to take on the marathon final dungeon.
[Time Master](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/TimeMaster): Unei, who can cast Haste.
[White Mage](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/WhiteMage): Unei's spells are from the White Magic side, though she deals in buffs and Holy.

[Who Wants to Live Forever?](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/WhoWantsToLiveForever): Doga and Unei agree that the gift Xande received from Noah, the gift of *Mortality*, was the greatest of them all. Xande disagrees.

[Wizard Classic](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/WizardClassic): Doga ticks most of the boxes: He wears robes, is very old, inherited great magical power from Noah and lives in a manor, filled with books and staffed only by moogles, that is the only point of interest on the continent that it's on. Said manor is also guarded by fierce winds that only an airship like the Nautilus can hope to get through.

[Greater-Scope Paragon](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/GreaterScopeParagon): He was the teacher of Doga and Unei, who went on to assist the Warriors of Light in their fight against Noah's rogue student Xande. He was also said to be able to use all forms of magic and sealed Leviathan and Bahamut on the Floating Continent, as he was the only one at the time who could summon them.
[Jack of All Trades](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/JackOfAllTrades): It's hinted that the Sage job is based upon him, as he was able to cast from all three schools of magic.
[Mono no Aware](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/MonoNoAware): It's hinted that he had this view, especially in unused dialogue for the 3D version, which led him to gift Xande his mortality.
[Posthumous Character](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/PosthumousCharacter): He died long before the beginning of the game, but his actions hold a lot of influence even in the present day.

[Unwitting Instigator of Doom](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/UnwittingInstigatorOfDoom): Giving Xande the gift of mortality was not Noah’s best decision, inadvertently causing his former student to go mad and freeze time by flooding the world in darkness to avoid dying.
